Last month, the Kurdish Labor Party kidnapped 10 Germans and released them eight days later.</p><p>AP</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Dr Allen Roberts . . . may have left a trail.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:6F7D-FNN3-RTWS-G25W-00000-00FIRE CHARS TOMBS1994-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:26ZLexisNexisPg. 46FIRE CHARS TOMBS

KEYWORD-HIT Fire chars tombs A YOUNG shepherd has been blamed for a forest fire that tore through a World War I battleground in the Gallipoli peninsula. War monuments and cemeteries holding Turkish and Allied dead were charred and a local fire chief died directing the effort to halt the blaze. ""The shepherd, Ahmet Uysal, 13, lit a fire to roast some corn on the cob, and the fire spread to a field of stubble,'' Forestry Minister Hasan Ekinci said. The boy was detained briefly and released, pending a hearing. The flames damaged some of the 50 military cemeteries and memorials in the area. IN the United States, two battalions of Marines will be sent to help fight fires in the north-west that have destroyed nearly 100 homes and other structures, officials said yesterday. The Marine reinforcements will add 1000 fire fighters to nearly 8000 men and women now battling to contain 30 major fires burning in Washington and Oregon. The fires, which were sparked by lightning strikes last weekend, have blackened more than 52,600ha of tinder-dry timber and grassland.

"Where they used artillery, we will use foam." The site of the fire is covered in flaming mounds of tyres and shredded rubber, shrouded in smoke and surrounded by trenches. The trenches have been dug to capture the run-off from melted tyres and oil is being skimmed off and pumped away by workers wearing gas masks for protection.</p><p> HERALD BUREAU</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">HERALDLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier Firefighters were battling a forest fire near Mt Beauty in Victoria's north-east as officials revealed that charges were pending against three people following earlier fires in the region.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Firefighters were back-burning to halt the latest fire at Coral Bank near Mt Beauty which broke out when a person was burning off, Natural Resources and Environment Department central fire coordinator Peter Billing said.</p><p>He said the fire had burned through about 35 hectares of forest and was one of three similar burn-off breakaway fires in the region at the weekend.</p><p> The others, at Eskdale and Dodds Bridge, between Mansfield and Benalla, also in the north-east, were under control late yesterday.</p><p> No serious damage was done by the fires in the forest areas.</p><p> But Mr Billing said there had been a total of 18 fires scattered across the state's north-east in the past fortnight and three people would be charged on summons over three of them.</p><p> He said they would be charged with failing to keep a fire they lit under control.</p><p> He said it pointed out how careful people must be when burning off to reduce fire fuel, that the fire did not get out of control.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4F20-0048-T0RY-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="200"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7M-D180-TXN5-R24W-00000-00GREENHOUSE MAY BOOST FIRE RISK1992-06-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:27ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 4GREENHOUSE MAY BOOST FIRE RISKCATHERINE ARMITAGE Science Writer

Increases in greenhouse gas emissions will cause a greater risk of bushfires, according to a CSIRO computer model.

It found that a doubling of greenhouse gases could lead to Ash Wednesday-type fire risks every summer in parts of Victoria and Western Australia.

The Ash Wednesday fires in 1983, which killed 75 people, were the result of a high-risk combination of factors such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and rainfall level.

These factors are used by the CSIRO's Division of Forestry and Monash University as inputs into a computer model which produces a Forest Fire Danger Index.

Dr Tom Beer, of the CSIRO, has found that relative humidity is the most important factor in estimating fire danger. The amount of moisture in leaf litter on the forest floor determines the fire's ability to generate high temperatures and spread rapidly.

When the model was used to predict what might happen if greenhouse gases doubled, it found the south-west of WA and East Gippsland in Victoria would become drier and more fire prone.

The member for Mulgrave, Mr Menzell, yesterday asked Sir Joh to schedule a Cabinet meeting in the stricken sugar town of Babinda.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>""We are in a dreadful situation up here, with sugar farmers going to the wall, and now the cyclone has just devastated locals," Mr Menzell said. ""It is important that Ministers see at first hand the extent of the calamity so they can devise a workable plan of assistance. ""There is no reason why a country Cabinet meeting could not be scheduled here." A Premier's Department spokesman said that Sir Joh was expected to respond favorably to the request and announce that Cabinet would meet in Babinda early in March. With Parliament sitting for two weeks from next Tuesday, March 3 would be the first available date. Forest fire threat, Page 13</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier L</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Killer fire still out of control BEIJING (AAP): Communist China's worst-ever forest fire, which has killed at least 172 people and left 51,000 homeless, raged out of control in the country's north-east today despite efforts to contain it, official reports said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Firebreaks were largely in place on the eastern side of the fire in a remote area of Heilongjiang province near the Sino-Soviet border, state-run evening television news said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The fire was raging near the city of Tahe, 680km north-west of the Heilongjiang capital of Harbin.</p><p>Tahe, with a population of 100,000, was safe after twice being threatened since the blaze broke out one week ago, the broadcast said.</p><p>The fire has blackened 547,000ha of land and charred 750,000 cubic metres of timber worth 130million yuan ($A49.30million), according to a Forestry Ministry official.</p><p>It also destroyed 431 tractors and trucks, 640,000 square metres of housing, and several bridges and communications facilities worth 276.7million yuan ($A105.36million) an official of the ministry's Fire-Fighting Headquarters said.</p><p>Earlier reports said the fire destroyed three towns, several villages and three railway stations.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5XKM-VYB1-DYG0-94PV-00000-00<published>2019-11-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Ulises Izquierdo<br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 27 AAP - Firefighters will take advantage of cooler conditions this week to undertake burning-out works at major fires in remote areas of northeast Victoria.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   It comesafter firefighters last week battled more than 60 blazes across the state and Melbourne registered the hottest November day in a hundred years.<br/>   The Bureau of Meteorology has forecast cooler weather this week for the state, with the Country Fire Authority predicting lower fire risks until Saturday as a result.<br/>   Forest Fire Management Victoria said communities may notice an increase in fire size and smoke as the burning-out works are undertaken.<br/>   ?It?s critically important that we undertake these works now ahead of potentially worsening fire weather,? Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume Deputy Chief Fire Officer Aaron Kennedy said.<br/>   ?The works involve burning out vegetation between the containment line and the fire to reduce the risk of the fire taking a run and potentially impacting communities.?<br/>    There were 17 fires still burning on Tuesday across Victoria's Alpine region, with no communities under threat.<br/>   Many mountain walking tracks were closed to ensure safety of people in the area, and hikers in Victoria's Mount Bogong High Plains were forced to leave the area.<br/>   All of them were ignited last Thursday as a result of dry lightning, the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning reported.<br/>    Two new fires also ignited by lightning were reported on Tuesday.<br/>    ?Extreme dryness, erratic winds and difficult terrain have made it challenging for crews to contain these fires,? Mr Kennedy said.<br/>   ?We are fully expecting to be working on these fires for a number of weeks, potentially right up until Christmas and beyond, if we don?t receive significant rainfall.?</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XKM-VYB1-DYG0-94PV-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-11-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="300"/><timeReceived>3:31 AM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5XS7-WM61-DYG0-92MY-00000-00<published>2019-12-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Aine Fox<br/>   SYDNEY, Dec 18 AAP - Australia has endured its driest spring on record,setting the scene for a devastating bushfire season in which fierce blazes have swept across the country.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   As the nation prepares for a sweltering heatwave and temperatures above 40C, the Bureau of Meteorology on Wednesday confirmed spring was also the second-warmest ever recorded.<br/>   Rainfall was 62 per cent below average, making the spring of 2019 the driest since the previous all-time low in 1967, the BOM said in a special climate statement.<br/>   "The low rainfall added to pre-existing rainfall deficiencies and low soil moisture, exacerbating the meteorologicaland hydrological drought conditions and meaning forest fuels remained dry," the BOM said.<br/>   The average maximum daytime temperature was 2.41C above average, the second-warmest on record behind 2014.<br/>   The country also struggled through record high fire weather danger - as measured using the Forest Fire Danger Index - in each of the country's states and territories during spring.<br/>   "The dangerous fire weather conditions during spring 2019 is consistent with the increasingly severe fireweather seen in many areas of the country, owing to increasing temperatures and reduced cool seasonrainfall," the BOM said.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XS7-WM61-DYG0-92MY-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-12-17</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="210"/><timeReceived>1:03 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 25 AAP - Hot and dry conditions with maximum temperatures in the low 30s have prompted a Total Fire Ban in Victoria's Northern Country and Mallee districts.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Severe Fire Danger is forecast for both regions, with conditions becoming less extreme towards the south of the state.<br/>   After a Thursday whereMelbourne broke a 100-year-old temperature record for November hitting 40.9C and creeping well into the 40s in the Mallee region and northern country towns, the weekend saw dozens of bushfires blazing across Victoria.<br/>   "This shows us what the risks will be in summer around Victoria, so we still have a long way to go to be ready,"Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said on Thursday.<br/>   Nine bushfire advices were still ongoing on Sunday evening.<br/>   Although no communities were under threat, a bushfire in the Alpine region forced the closure of a number of walking tracks, with hikers advised to leave the area.<br/>   Most of the fires alight during the weekend have been in steep, remote country where the risk of falling trees adds to the difficulty for firefighters to access.<br/>   ?The remote locations of these fires are proving to be challenging for our crews and we fully expect them to burn for a number of weeks as firefighters work hard to contain them," Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume Deputy Chief Fire Officer Aaron Kennedy said.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 25 AAP - Hot and dry conditions with maximum temperatures in the low 30s have prompted a Total Fire Ban in Victoria's Northern Country and Mallee districts.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Severe Fire Danger is forecast for both regions, with conditions becoming less extreme towards the south of the state.<br/>   After a Thursday whereMelbourne broke a 100-year-old temperature record for November hitting 40.9C and creeping well into the 40s in the Mallee region and northern country towns, the weekend saw dozens of bushfires blazing across Victoria.<br/>   "This shows us what the risks will be in summer around Victoria, so we still have a long way to go to be ready,"Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said on Thursday.<br/>   Nine bushfire advices were still ongoing on Sunday evening.<br/>   Although no communities were under threat, a bushfire in the Alpine region forced the closure of a number of walking tracks, with hikers advised to leave the area.<br/>   Most of the fires alight during the weekend have been in steep, remote country where the risk of falling trees adds to the difficulty for firefighters to access.<br/>   ?The remote locations of these fires are proving to be challenging for our crews and we fully expect them to burn for a number of weeks as firefighters work hard to contain them," Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume Deputy Chief Fire Officer Aaron Kennedy said.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:5XJY-1411-DYG0-930H-00000-00<published>2019-11-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:26Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 23 AAP - Firefighters are hoping mild weekend conditions will help them control blazes caused by lightning in remote patches of forest in Victoria'snortheast.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   About 30 fires were still burning in Victoria on Friday afternoon, 20 of them located in hard-to-reach forested areas of the state's northeast.<br/>   Forest Fire Management Victoria said aircraft including big air tankers from Canberra and Sydney are being used to fight the forest blazes.<br/>   ?The aim is to get on top of them with the milder conditions," the authority's Hume deputy chief fire officerAaron Kennedy said.<br/>   More than 50 firefighting trucks, dozers and other heavy plant were also set to work on Friday to build containment lines and deal with dangerous trees.<br/>   But the remoteness of the fires isn't making their job easy.<br/>   "There is a lot of work to do in very difficult conditions," MrKennedy said.<br/>   More than 150 blazes burned across the state on Thursday,when record-breaking temperatures and strong winds lashed the state.<br/>   The CFA believes lightning or campfires started many of them.<br/>   Melbourne broke a 100-year-old temperature record for November on Thursday, with the mercury hitting 40.9C and creeping well into the 40s in the Mallee region and northern country towns.<br/>   Temperatures cooled on Friday, with emergency services now turning their attention to Monday when the temperature and fire risk are set to rise again, a CFA spokesman told AAP.<br/>   On Monday temperatures are expected to reach the high 30s in the state's north - the driest part of the state - and 32C in central Melbourne.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XJY-1411-DYG0-930H-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-11-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="266"/><timeReceived>3:30 AM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:4BDR-7T40-00VK-2430-00000-00<published>2004-01-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>NSW: Goonoo State Forest fire under control</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>SYDNEY, Jan 8</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p/><p nitf:lede="true"> More than 300 firefighters working for days to contain a bushfire in central NSW have brought the blaze under control.</p><p nitf:lede="true">NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman Cameron Wade said cooler temperatures and a change in wind direction had aided fire crews, who for the past three days tirelessly dug containment lines around the blaze.</p><p>The fire, which burned through more than 2000ha of bushland, erupted in the Goonoo State Forest, 25km north east of Dubbo on Monday.</p><p>It came within 7km of the small township of Ballimore, which was placed on high alert yesterday.</p><p>Mr Wade said the fire service would officially declare the fire contained within the next few hours.<br/>    Fire crews would be scaled back but local firefighters would remain for another day or so to "mop up", he said.</p><p>"You could certainly say it is under control," Mr Wade said.</p><p>"They will be an official declaration of containment in the next couple of hours.</p><p>"The only thing that has stopped this fire is basically the volunteer firefighters."</p><p>Meanwhile, NRMA Insurance advised NSW residents to immediate action to protect their properties in case of more fires which could break out due to high temperatures and low humidity forecast this week.</p><p>NRMA Insurance, Head of Product & Underwriting, Graeme Adams also reminded holiday makers who were driving along country roads and through bush land not to throw cigarettes out the window.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Peter Mitchell, AAP US Correspondent<br/>   LOS ANGELES, Dec 3 AAP - Firefighters from provinces across Canada have volunteered to give up Christmas with their families and fly to Australia to help with the bushfire crisis.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Thecrack team has answered Australia's call for help duringwhat's expected to be a dangerous bushfire season.<br/>   Australian officials submitted an official request tothe Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, based in Winnipeg, on Friday and on the weekend, dozens of experienced firefighters from provinces across Canada volunteered to give up Christmas with their families and fly to Australia.<br/>   A group of 21 firefighters was selected and will gather in Vancouver on Tuesday before flying to Sydney for what an expected 38-day deployment.<br/>   "We are pleased to help the people of Australia as they face these devastating fires, especially since Manitoba has been on the receiving end of help from friends and neighbours when wildfires and other natural disasters hit our province," premier of the Canadian province of Manitoba, Brian Pallister,said.<br/>   Manitoba is sending two firefighters withBritish Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario and Parks Canada contributing 19 others.<br/>   Strong bonds between Manitoba and Australia were built in the most unfortunate circumstances in July and August.<br/>   Canadian teenagers Kam McLeod and Bryer Schmegelsky shot dead Australian tourist Lucas Fowler and his girlfriend Chynna Deese on the side of a British Columbia highway and then fled to Manitoba, sparking a massive manhunt involving the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian military.<br/>   "There's nothing more Manitoban than offering a helping hand when someone else is in need," Mr Pallister said.<br/>   As Australia burns, Canada is heading into winter where temperatures will drop below20 degrees Celsius.<br/>   Theassigned firefighters were selected for their unique skill sets.<br/>   The Canadians will assist with a variety of roles within the incident management team, including planning, aviation and operations.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Peter Mitchell, AAP US Correspondent<br/>   LOS ANGELES, Dec 3 AAP - The Canadians are coming.<br/>   A crack group of Canadian firefighters have answered Australia's call for help to fight devastating bushfires.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Australian officials submitted an official request tothe Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, based in Winnipeg, on Friday and on the weekend, dozens of experienced firefighters from provinces across Canada volunteered to give up Christmas with their families and fly to Australia.<br/>   A group of 21 firefighters were selected from the applicants and will gather in Vancouver on Tuesday before flying to Sydney for what is expected to be a 38-day deployment.<br/>   "We are pleased to help the people of Australia as they face these devastating fires, especially since Manitoba has been on the receiving end of help from friends and neighbours when wildfires and other natural disasters hit our province," premier of the Canadian province of Manitoba, Brian Pallister,said.<br/>   Manitoba is sending two firefighters withBritish Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario and Parks Canada contributing 19 others.<br/>   Strong bonds between Manitoba and Australia were built in the most unfortunate circumstances in July and August.<br/>   Canadian teenagers Kam McLeod and Bryer Schmegelsky shot dead Australian tourist Lucas Fowler and his girlfriend Chynna Deese on the side of a British Columbia highway and then fled to Manitoba, sparking a massive manhunt involving the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian military.<br/>   "There's nothing more Manitoban than offering a helping hand when someone else is in need," Mr Pallister said.<br/>   As Australia burns, Canada is heading into winter where temperatures will drop below20 degrees Celsius.<br/>   Theassigned firefighters were selected for their unique skill sets.<br/>   The Canadians will assist with a variety of roles within the incident management team, including planning, aviation and operations.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Dec 2 AAP - A bulldozer operator has been killed while helping fight a bushfire in Victoria's Gippsland region.<br/>   The man aged in his 60s died late on Saturday at the fires near Gelantipy, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said on Monday.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   He was working on earth breaks on private property so that firefighters could battle a blaze on public land.<br/>   "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team, personally it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," Mr Hardman told reporters, without revealing the specific cause of the man's death.<br/>   "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people."<br/>   The man was from the East Gippsland region and had helped fire crews in the past.<br/>   Victoria Police are preparing a report for the coroner and WorkSafe is also investigating.<br/>   Fires continue to burn in Victoria's east.<br/>   Incident controller Peter Brick said while there had been cooler conditions at the weekend, the underlying drought means fire activity could quickly ramp up when the warmer weather returns.<br/>   "We can't reiterate enough how dry the land is across Gippsland at the moment," he told reporters.<br/>   "Now's the time to prepare."<br/>   While fires burn, parts of the state have been dumped with snow in a chilly start to summer.<br/>   Falls Creek received a dumping overnight and on Monday morning, as did Mount Buller and Mount Hotham.<br/>   Great Alpine Road between Harrietville and Hotham had to be cleared of snow on Monday morning and drivers were warned more was expected to come.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Dec 2 AAP - A bulldozer operator has been killed while helping fight a bushfire in Victoria's Gippsland region.<br/>   The man aged in his 60s died late on Saturday at the fires near Gelantipy, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said on Monday.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   He was working on earth breaks on private property so that firefighters could battle a blaze on public land.<br/>   "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team, personally it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," Mr Hardman told reporters, without revealing the specific cause of the man's death.<br/>   "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people."<br/>   The man was from the East Gippsland region and had helped fire crews in the past.<br/>   Victoria Police are preparing a report for the coroner and WorkSafe is also investigating.<br/>   Fires continue to burn in Victoria's east.<br/>   Incident controller Peter Brick said while there had been cooler conditions at the weekend, the underlying drought means fire activity could quickly ramp up when the warmer weather returns.<br/>   "We can't reiterate enough how dry the land is across Gippsland at the moment," he told reporters.<br/>   "Now's the time to prepare."<br/>   While fires burn, parts of the state have been dumped with snow in a chilly start to summer.<br/>   Falls Creek received a dumping overnight and on Monday morning, as did Mount Buller and Mount Hotham.<br/>   Great Alpine Road between Harrietville and Hotham had to be cleared of snow on Monday morning and drivers were warned more was expected to come.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Cheryl Goodenough<br/>   BRISBANE, Nov 15 AAP - Suburbs being built alongside pockets of bush in outer Brisbane have a greater risk of going up in flames than homes in other states, a bushfire building expert believes.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Lower bushfire resilience standards in Queensland mean hundreds of houses could be lost if fire raced through some new Brisbane developments, architect Ian Weir says.<br/>   "It's a disaster waiting to happen," Dr Weir, a founder of the Bushfire Building Council of Australia, told AAP.<br/>   Dr Weir, of the Queensland University of Technology, says homes in the state don't have to be asbushfire resilient as they are required to be in New South Wales and Victoria.<br/>   New developments in suburbs like Yarrabilba, south of Brisbane and Springfield, near Ipswich, backed onto bushland are built to standard but at risk, he said.<br/>   "You would only need a couple of houses ignited and you'd need to evacuate people," he said.<br/>   "Then you'd have houses on fire, igniting neighbouring houses."<br/>   Houses in bushfire prone parts of Victoriahave to be built to a forest fire danger index (FFDI) of 100, while in Queensland the standard is just 40, the lowest in Australia, he said.<br/>   "Nationally the weakest link is in Queensland," Dr Weir said.<br/>   He called on the Queensland Government to raise the state's FFDI.<br/>   He also wants the state to make it mandatory for assessors ofbushfire attack levels (BAL), who determine a building's risk and protection required, to be fully accredited.<br/>   Queensland is the only state that does not require such accreditation.<br/>   A Queensland housing department spokesperson said the government ensured the fire danger rating for the construction of buildings prioritised safety.<br/>   "Given the real threat of bushfires across Queensland communities, this is something we review regularly," the spokesperson said.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Dec 2 AAP - A bulldozer operator has died while helping fight a bushfire in Victoria's Gippsland region,bringing the work-related death toll to three in the last six days.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The 69-year-old man died late on Saturday at the fires near Gelantipy, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said on Monday.<br/>   He was working on earth breaks on private propertyfor the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planningso that firefighters could battle a blaze on public land.<br/>   WorkSafe believes the man lost control of his 4WD utility while driving down a steep embankment and was thrown from his vehicle when it rolled, suffering fatal injuries.<br/>   "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team, personally it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," Mr Hardman told reporters on Monday.<br/>   "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people."<br/>   The man was from the East Gippsland region and has helped fire crews in the past.<br/>   Victoria Police are preparing a report for the coroner and WorkSafe is also investigating.<br/>   Fires continue to burn in Victoria's east, despite rain and snow in some areas.<br/>   Incident controller Peter Brick said while there had been cooler conditions on the weekend, the underlying drought means fire activity could quickly ramp up when the warmer weather returns.<br/>   "We can't reiterate enough how dry the land is across Gippsland at the moment," he told reporters.<br/>   "Now's the time to prepare."<br/>   While fires burn, parts of the state have been dumped with snow in a chilly start to summer.<br/>   Falls Creek received snowfall overnight and on Monday morning, as did Mount Buller and Mount Hotham.<br/>   The Great Alpine Road between Harrietville and Hotham had to be cleared of snow on Monday morning and drivers were warned more was expected to come.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:5XN2-PYC1-DYG0-9124-00000-00<published>2019-12-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Dec 2 AAP - A bulldozer operator has died while helping fight a bushfire in Victoria's Gippsland region,bringing the work-related death toll to three in the last six days.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The 69-year-old man died late on Saturday at the fires near Gelantipy, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said on Monday.<br/>   He was working on earth breaks on private propertyfor the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planningso that firefighters could battle a blaze on public land.<br/>   WorkSafe believes the man lost control of his 4WD utility while driving down a steep embankment and was thrown from his vehicle when it rolled, suffering fatal injuries.<br/>   "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team, personally it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," Mr Hardman told reporters on Monday.<br/>   "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people."<br/>   The man was from the East Gippsland region and has helped fire crews in the past.<br/>   Victoria Police are preparing a report for the coroner and WorkSafe is also investigating.<br/>   Fires continue to burn in Victoria's east, despite rain and snow in some areas.<br/>   Incident controller Peter Brick said while there had been cooler conditions on the weekend, the underlying drought means fire activity could quickly ramp up when the warmer weather returns.<br/>   "We can't reiterate enough how dry the land is across Gippsland at the moment," he told reporters.<br/>   "Now's the time to prepare."<br/>   While fires burn, parts of the state have been dumped with snow in a chilly start to summer.<br/>   Falls Creek received snowfall overnight and on Monday morning, as did Mount Buller and Mount Hotham.<br/>   The Great Alpine Road between Harrietville and Hotham had to be cleared of snow on Monday morning and drivers were warned more was expected to come.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:5X2F-YC61-DYG0-9008-00000-00<published>2019-09-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>   SYDNEY, Sept 16 AAP - Conditions are expected to improve for NSW firefighters after strong winds caused "erratic" fire behaviour and saw two major blazes flare up in the state's north.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The NSW Rural Fire Service issued emergency warnings for one bushfire at Drake and another east of Glen Innes in the Brother State Forest on Monday afternoon.<br/>   The Brother State Forest blaze was ultimately downgraded in the evening.<br/>   RFS inspector Ben Shepherd said strengthening northwesterlies had caused some "quite erratic fire behaviour" on Monday, but conditions should be more favourable on Tuesday.<br/>   "The bureau has indicated there is the chance now of some thunderstorm activity - which may result in some lightning - so we will be watching that carefully," he said.<br/>   On Monday afternoon, RFS deputy commissioner Rob Rogers said the Drake blaze was threatening properties in the Drake and Red Rock areas and they had advised residents to "prepare for fire impact".<br/>   "It's causing fire crews a lot of problems today," he told ABC News.<br/>   The 16,000ha Brother State Forest fire was given a Watch and Act alert after the threat to homes eased on Monday night, but the blaze was still burning out of control.<br/>   Several schools in the vicinity of both fires will be closed on Tuesday.<br/>   The flare-ups come after fire conditions across NSW eased on Sunday, with firefighters gaining the upper hand on a number of blazes.<br/>   But Monday's weather, including strong wind warnings up and down the NSW coast, caused fresh headaches.<br/>   Fifty-seven bush and grass fires were burning in the afternoon and about 20 were not contained.<br/>   Mr Rogers said a 92,000ha bushfire in Bees Nest near Armidale was "nowhere near contained" but was not threatening properties.<br/>   Most regions of NSW have been given a low-moderate fire danger rating on Tuesday.<br/>   However, New England and the Northern Slopes face a very high fire danger, while the North Western and Far North Coast regions have been given a high fire danger rating.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5X6X-6WS1-DYG0-929B-00000-00<published>2019-10-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:26Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Liza Kappelle<br/>   BRISBANE, Oct 7 AAP - Firefighters are urging Queenslanders to beware of dangerous fire conditions as they battle bushfires in sweltering conditions.<br/>   Dry and windy conditions are pushing temperatures in some parts of the state up to 12C above average for October on Monday, the Bureau of Meteorology says.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Brisbane is expected to reach 34 degrees while further inland, at Esk, Ipswich, Laidley and Gatton, 40 degrees is expected.<br/>   Rural Fire Service acting director Wayne Waltisbuhl says there are about 15 fires burning across Queensland on Monday.<br/>   The two most significant are at Glen Rock State Forest, south of Gatton, and Swanfels, north-north east of Warwick.<br/>   The Glen Rock State Forest fire started a week ago from a lightning strike, MrWaltisbuhl says.<br/>   Aircraft are water-bombing to slow down the blaze so ground crews can try to contain the fire which has come out of inaccessible country to grazing land.<br/>   "Its going to be pretty tough because by about midday/early afternoon the bad weather conditions are going to impact," he told AAP.<br/>   On Monday morning it was burning in the vicinity of Cole Gully Road in the Lefthand Branch area.<br/>   Severe fire danger conditions are forecast for the bone dry Darling Downs and Granite Belt, and Maranoa and Warrego districts.<br/>   There is the potential for pockets of extreme fire danger conditions in the southern, forested parts of these districts, the Bureau of Meteorology says.<br/>   The fire at Swanfels was also started by lightning strike and fire crews hope to contain it as much as possible before more dangerous conditions set in.<br/>   Mr Waltisbuhl says the fires of most concern, however, are those that haven't started yet.<br/>   He is urging Queenslanders to have fire plans ready to enact, including grab bags with things to take in an emergency.<br/>   Firefighters are also urging people to be careful of sparking fires, with temperaturesexpected to remain high in the southeast until Wednesday.<br/>   Queensland has had a destructive start to the bushfire season with massive fires forcing evacuations, with the worst in the Scenic Rim, Sunshine Coast and Granite Belt regions.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5HVS-T4D1-JD67-108M-00000-00<published>2016-01-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FRONTPAGE</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Brendan Wrigley</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Branches of the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning will undergo another name change in the coming months, as forest firefighters take on the Forest Fire Management brand.</p><p nitf:lede="true">DELWP vehicles and uniforms will be re-branded under the name change, while new personal protective clothing will also be labelled with the new name.</p><p>The change comes after a review into the Lancefield-Cobaw fire, where an out of control burn off sparked a 4000 hectare fire bushfire. </p><p>While the DELWP refused to disclosed how much the roll out of the new title would cost, a DELWP spokesperson said the department would take 'all necessary steps' to ensure costs were kept to a minimum.</p><p>'The development of a brand for forest firefighters that is recognisable and long lasting was one of the recommendations from the independent investigation into the Lancefield-Cobaw fire.'</p><p>The Courier understands the branch name change will allow firefighters to remain under the same title if the department was to again change names in the future.</p><p>The move comes after the department name change from Department of Environment and Primary Industries (DEPI) to DELWP in February 2015 following the change of state government.</p><p>Ballarat MP Joshua Morris said while it was important forest firefighters were recognised for their work , it was important the money went towards helping to fight fires.</p><p>'The recommendations for this name change is a direct result of Labor's ongoing restructuring and rebranding of government departments.'</p><p>'We always want to see government money well spent.'</p><p>The DELWP is also proposing a major internal restructure which will create a new Forest Fire and Regions group.</p><p>The new group would take elements from the current Fire and Emergency Management Division and other parts of its current Land, Fire and Environment Group and the Regional Services Group.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5XK5-08X1-DYG0-9374-00000-00<published>2019-11-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Marnie Banger<br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 23 AAP - More than a dozen fires are still burning in remote patches of forest in Victoria's northeast, while 10 blazes remain active across the Gippsland region.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   But firefighters have made progress in stamping out fires in both areas.<br/>   The blazes emerged after Victoria was lashed with hot weather and strong winds on Thursday.<br/>   Lightning was largely responsible for about 30 fires in the northeast, 16 of which were still burning on Saturday.<br/>   The others have been put out with the help of large air tankers, including aircraft borrowed from NSW and the ACT, and cooler weekend weather.<br/>   Forest Fire Management Victoria expects the remaining fires could take up to a few weeks to get under control, while the return of hot weather next week may not help crews battling the flames.<br/>   ?We are throwing all resources that we have at this fire and working closely with the CFA to try and contain as many of these fires as we can before we see an increase in temperatures across the region on Monday,"the authority's Hume deputy chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy said on Saturday.<br/>   More than 200 firefighters remain on the ground to battle the forest blazes.<br/>   Ten fires continue to burn in Gippsland, most north of Bairnsdale, stretching up as far as Shannonvale in the far north of the region. Several others have been contained in the last couple of days.<br/>   Most of the fires have been in steep, remote country where the risk of falling trees adds to the difficulty for firefighters to access.<br/>   CFA Gippsland Regional Controller Ben Rankin said there is a "significant body of work" still to be done.<br/>   "We are utilising every resource available to us and that includes ground crews, heavy machinery and aircraft," he said on Saturday.<br/>   More than 150 blazes burned across the state on Thursday, with theCFA believing lightning or campfires started many of them.<br/>   Melbourne broke a 100-year-old temperature record for November on the day, with the mercury hitting 40.9C and creeping well into the 40s in the Mallee region and northern country towns.<br/>   Temperatures cooled on Friday, with emergency services now turning their attention to Monday when the temperature are set to rise again.<br/>   On Monday temperatures are expected to reach the mid-30s in the state's north and 28C in central Melbourne.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XK5-08X1-DYG0-9374-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-11-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="389"/><timeReceived>7:26 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>changes keyword from Heat Qld<br/>Liza Kappelle<br/>   BRISBANE, Oct 7 AAP - Firefighters battling several big blazes in hot, windy weather in Queensland are urging people to prepare for fire danger.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   There were about 15 fires burning around the state on Monday amid severe fire conditions in tinder dry southern Queensland.<br/>   The Darling Downs and Granite Belt, and Maranoa and Warrego districts are most at risk from the severe conditions expected for both Monday and Tuesday.<br/>   The Bureau of Meteorology says there is the potential for pockets of extreme fire danger conditions in the southern, forested parts of these districts.<br/>   Rural Fire Service acting director Wayne Waltisbuhl told AAP on Monday morning the twomost significant were at Glen Rock State Forest, south of Gatton, and Swanfels, north-north east of Warwick.<br/>   Later in the day, a prepare to leave notice was issued for a bushfire further north at Mount Morgan, Struck Oil, Leydens Hill and Baree in case conditions get worse.<br/>   Mr Waltisbuhl said the Glen Rock State Forest fire started a week ago from a lightning strike and has emerged out of the national park and into grazing land.<br/>   Aircraft were water-bombing to slow down the blaze for ground crews trying to contain the fire.<br/>   Mr Waltisbuhl warned tougher conditions would hit as the day progressed and by early afternoon the bad weatherhad impacted.<br/>   People nearby were warned to prepare to leave as the fire was burning in an easterly direction near Cole Gully Road, Lefthand Branch and there were fears it could impact properties along Cole Gully Road.<br/>   Dry and windy conditions have pushed temperatures in some parts of the state up to 12C above average for October on Monday, the Bureau of Meteorology said.<br/>   Brisbane is expected to reach 34 degrees while in the Lockyer Valley at Ipswich, Laidley and Gatton, 40 degrees is expected.<br/>   Firefighters are monitoring the fire at Swanfels which is burning in inaccessible land near Dollar Bill Road. It started last week after lightning and expected to burn for several days.<br/>   Mr Waltisbuhl says the fires of most concern are those that haven't started yet, but which could start at any time by more lightning or human error in the dangerous conditions.<br/>   He is urging Queenslanders to have fire plans ready to enact, including 'grab bags' with things to take in an emergency.<br/>   Firefighters are also urging people to be careful of sparking fires, with temperaturesexpected to remain high in the southeast until Wednesday.<br/>   Queensland's bushfire season began in September with massive fires forcing evacuations - the worst in the Scenic Rim, Sunshine Coast and Granite Belt regions.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5X6X-KGJ1-DYG0-92CG-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-10-07</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="443"/><timeReceived>3:08 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5XJH-2RP1-DYG0-9289-00000-00<published>2019-11-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FINANCIAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Derek Rose<br/>   SYDNEY, Nov 21 AAP - Climate change will expose Australians to just about every type of extreme weather, from floods and cyclones todevastating bushfires, according to a report by one of Australia's biggest insurers.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   "Climate change is already well underway and is considered by many to be the greatest risk currently facing humanity," says the report, which was released on Thursday as smoke from massive bushfires burning north of Sydney shrouded the city in haze.<br/>   The report, released by IAG and the US National Center for Atmospheric Research, says extreme weather is already occurring more frequently in Australia and will change "at a higher amplitude than more common events".<br/>   "This is because small changes in the mean climate lead to dramatic changes in the extremes," the report says.<br/>   "When are we going to see extreme weather? We've seen them already," Cindy Bruyere, director of NCAR'sCenter for Climate and Weather Extremes, said in a presentation released with the report.<br/>   It found the world has entered a new era of global tropical cyclones and destructive ones are expected to increase in southeast Queensland and northeast NSW.<br/>   Intense, short-duration rainfall can be expected to increase across the country, resulting in flooding in urban areas and small river catchments.<br/>   Damaging hailstorms with stones larger than 5cmare likely in NSW from the Hunter River south to the southern NSW highlands, as well as central and eastern Victoria, the report says.<br/>   Data from the Bureau of Meteorology and old media reports highlighted the unprecedented nature of record-setting hail in March 2010 in Perth and Melbourne and in November 2016 in Adelaide.<br/>   "There are no historical analogues prior to these major events and these areas have been well populated for the past century or more without any recorded analogues," the report says.<br/>   Sydney has also experienced four major hailstorms since 2015, which the report said was "without precedent in its long historical record", although the worst hailstorm in Sydney remains one from April 1999.<br/>   Bushfires are the result of a complex interaction between weather, climate, vegetation and people, and so is challenging to simulate, the report notes.<br/>   Still there is "high confidence" that climate change will increase the number of days where the Forest Fire Danger Index is severe in southern and eastern Australia.<br/>   "There is compelling information that bushfire is one of the fastest growing climate risks facing Australia," the report says.<br/>   Under 4C of warming, the frequency of severe fire danger days could triple in eastern Australia, it says.<br/>   Rising sea levels could also pose increase the risks such as storm surge, riverine flooding and coastal erosion for a large number of sites along the Australian coastline, with rapid changes especially predicted for the Australian east and southeast coasts as well as New Zealand's North Island.<br/>   IAG managing director and CEO Peter Harmer said Australia urgently needed to prepare for climate change.<br/>   "This report shows that our climate is changing more rapidly than some have predicted so it is critical there is a co-ordinated national approach from governments, industries and businesses," he said.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5B6J-CDR1-F0NH-V05X-00000-00<published>2014-01-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>SAM POTTS</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The hot, dry weather of recent weeks has made its presence felt as fire fighters contend with a blaze in the Wollemi National Park east of Mudgee.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A forest fire at Girribung Creek, east of Gospers Mountain in the Wollemi National Park, started prior to Christmas is listed as 'being controlled' and has burnt over 13,000ha.</p><p>The fire is in a remote area of the National Park and due to that the firefighting is being performed mainly by air.</p><p>Six aircraft are being used for waterbombing and for the deployment of Remote Area Firefighting Teams (RAFT) personnel.</p><p>The fire forced the closure of the park's areas, roads and walking trails.</p><p>On a number of days wind pushed smoke from the Girribung Creek fire into surrounding areas including the Mid-Western Region, as well as Sydney, the Blue Mountains and Bathurst.</p><p>On Christmas Eve ,Mudgee was blanketed in smoke and a week later a plume emanating from the National Park could be seen from the Castlereagh Highway.</p><p>The fire started on December 21 but the combination of the remote area, the size of the 'fuel' available, hot and windy weather, and the shear size have slowed efforts to extinguish it.</p><p>Rain in the area on Christmas Day only had a minor effect on the fire and the Rural Fire Service say that it would take a solid several days of rain to really help.</p><p>Also in the Wollemi during the Christmas period was the Capertee River South fire, on ridgeline between Capertee and Wolgan Rivers, was brought under control having burnt 50ha.</p><p>In the vicinity were a two-hectare forest fire at Glen Alice and a two-hectare fire at Capertee, which were brought under control.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5MB2-MK41-F0JP-W1RX-00000-00<published>2016-12-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 3</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Appeal for food Embrace the spirit of Christmas and think of the less fortunate. You can donate to the Wesley Food for Families Appeal. For a list of drop-off points for donations of non-perishable items, go to wesley.org.au</p><p>Honour citizens Nominations for Yarra Ranges Australia Day Awards are open and residents are invited to get involved. Mayor Noel Cliff encouraged the community to nominate someone who has inspired them. Categories include Citizen, Young Citizen, Environmental Achiever, Ken McIntosh Memorial Award, Community Group, Mayor's Lifetime Achievement Award.</p><p>Nominations close Monday, December 12. Details: yarraranges.vic.gov.au</p><p>Firewood banFirewood collection season has come to an end as of December 1. Forest Fire Management Victoria forest and fire operations regional manager Peter Kambouris said it was illegal for people to collect firewood on public land until the start of the designated season. Department staff will patrol parks, forests and reserves to make sure people are doing the right thing. Mr Kambouris said on-the-spot fines were $622, and those people with offences that go to court could be liable for up to $7773, a year in jail or both. "The public will be able to start collecting firewood again from designated firewood collection areas from March 1, 2017, pending suitable conditions." he said. Details: delwp.vic.gov.au/firewood or 136 186</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5BFC-FGN1-F0NH-V12P-00000-00<published>2014-02-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>ELENA GUARRACINO</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A LARGE dangerous forest fire at Shannons Flat is burning out of control and is heading towards the Namadji National Park in the ACT.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Monaro Team Rural Fire Service planning officer Ailish Pope said the fire had 'jumped' the northern containment line at about 12 midday on Monday but crews were on site and dealing with the 'spot over'.</p><p>"Residents on the Billilingra Road in the Nightingale area have been issued with a 'watch and act' warning as a precaution in case the fire runs in an easterly direction," Ms Pope said.</p><p>Deputy incident controller Pam O'Brien (National Parks and Wildlife Service) said the fire started on private property on Friday afternoon.</p><p>"The cause of the fire is not known," she said.</p><p>"It is under investigation, and no lightning strikes were recorded in the area at the time.</p><p>"It is a large forest fire burning is steep rugged terrain.</p><p>"It is in bushland and we have 10 aircraft on the job today [Monday]."</p><p>"We have local fire crews and outside crews - ACT strike teams and strike teams from away."</p><p>The fire which has burnt 1210 hectares since it started four days ago, and has been classified as 'being controlled'.</p><p>Called the 'Murrumbucca' fire, it has been declared a Section 44 fire - an official state of emergency - enabling the Rural Fire Service to call on additional resources outside the area, which has included other agencies such as National Parks and Wildlife, Fire and Rescue NSW, police and strike teams.</p><p>A total of 19 tankers, 75 firefighters, four bulldozers, four bulk water tankers and ten aircraft - all have been battling the fire.</p><p>The fire is 23 kilometres from Cooma, between the Shannons Flat Road and Billilingra Road, and has continued to burn in a northerly direction towards Namadji National Park in the ACT.</p><p>Fire crews protected the Amaroo and Murrumbucca homesteads which were threatened by the blaze.</p><p>Ms O'Brien said back burning and more containment lines are planned along the north west containment lines on Monday night which will result in a containment line around the entire fire.</p><p>With easing fire condition predicted for today (Tuesday) Ms O'Brien said it is hoped the fire will be contained to its current size, and firefighters can start to mop up and blackout the fire.</p><p>A number of other fires, on the Monaro have also kept local fire crews busy, are under control and contained.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">COOMAM-2063256</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">COOMAM2014</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5BFC-FGN1-F0NH-V12P-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">390480</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2018-03-16</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="388"/><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2014 Fairfax Media Publications Pty. urn:contentItem:5J8H-6HJ1-JD67-14RG-00000-00<published>2016-03-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Olivia Shying</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">DELIBERATELY lit fires quickly spread to a pine plantation in Creswick, burning more than two hectares.</p><p nitf:lede="true">CFA operations officer Gavin Hope said three fires had been lit along the Creswick train line, above the three arches bridge on Bald Hills roads.</p><p>Police and firefighters were called to the scene just before 1am on Wednesday morning. </p><p>Creswick police confirmed a stolen ute from Ballarat had been torched under the bridge.</p><p>Mr Hope said the fires quickly spread into the plantation. Eight CFA units were required to extinguish the blaze, which was still being blacked out at 10am on Wednesday.</p><p>'These fires started a forest fire that quickly spread,' Mr Hope said.</p><p>Mr Hope said firefighters remained extremely frustrated as people continued to light fires.</p><p>He said these deliberately lit fires posed a risk to the community and used valuable resources.</p><p>A V/Line media spokeswoman confirmed V/Line had been notified of a 'smouldering sleeper' on the Creswick line. </p><p>She did not expect this to interfere with any regular services.</p><p>The fires come just days after the emergency services minister Jane Garrett said Victoria had a problem with arsonists. A number of major fires in the area, including fires at Mount Bolton and Lucas are being investigated.</p><p>Anyone with further information is urged to contact CrimeStoppers on 1800 333 000. </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">BALCOU-3779011</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:5HWD-P3T1-F0N8-R2KM-00000-00<published>2016-01-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>OPINION</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>TIM ROBERTS</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Africa is dreaming of having its own Great Wall, not of stone as in China, but of trees. </p><p nitf:lede="true">A germ of an idea in 2005 has now become a commitment by a contiguous band of countries to create the Great Green Wall of Africa stretching across the continent below the Sahara. Aimed at combatting desertification, degradation of soils and poverty, the Green Wall will be a strip of land 15- kilometres wide and some 7000 kilometres long stretching from Senegal on the west coast through Mauritania, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, Nigeria, Chad, Sudan, and Ethiopia to Eritrea and Djibouti on the east coast of Africa.</p><p>Senegal is leading the push. Each year since 2008, some 400 Senegalese are employed in eight nurseries, choosing and overseeing germination of seeds and tending the seedlings until they are ready for planting. Indigenous tree species have been chosen for their hardiness and their economic uses as food, forage, cooking oil, folk medicine and cosmetics. Then 1000 people are mobilised to plant out rows of seedlings - about two million plants - allowing them a full two months of the rainy season to take root before the long, dry season sets in. So far, 30,000 hectares have been planted.</p><p>Newly-planted trees are protected from hungry animals by fencing for six years ' time for their roots to reach down to groundwater and their branches to grow higher than the animals can reach. Unplanted strips protect the parcels from forest fire and provide passageways for herders' livestock.</p><p>Sensors to record temperatures in some planted parcels have shown that the trees moderate the daily temperature extremes. The trees also have an important role in slowing the soil erosion caused by wind, reducing dust, and halting sand-laden winds from the Sahara.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:51MS-01J1-F0JP-W4DR-00000-00<published>2010-12-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 29</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fire watchers the best</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Forest Fire Lookout Association has welcomed a report by the CSIRO on the trial of bushfire detection cameras.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The trial results indicated there was a one in 25 chance that a fire would be detected in a timely fashion by a detection camera or sensor and there was little information that a fire would be detected at a small enough size for a first attack to be successful.</p><p>This is compared to the human-operated fire towers used as a benchmark in the report that showed the fire would be detected quickly and accurately. The fire spotters had close to 100 per cent success in detecting fires used in the trial, compared to the cameras trialled that only managed to detect one in five fires.</p><p>Graphs in the trial indicated that the lowest-ranking detections by the human-based system were ahead of the highest-ranking detections of the more expensive camera/sensor-based systems.</p><p>It is hoped that, with the results being so strongly in favour of human-operated fire lookouts, the Federal Government would support our rural communities and commit funding for continued maintenance and operation of Fire Lookouts.</p><p>Paul Jones, Australian Chapter of the Forest Fire Lookout Association</p><p>Staff station, cut vandalism</p><p>METRO Trains spokesman Chris Whitefield was quoted in Leader saying many train stations no longer had toilets open because they attracted vandalism. So 99 per cent of people who don't vandalise the toilets are penalised.</p><p>What is stopping them opening during peak periods? Do it and let's see what happens. I think vandals are absent when there are lots of users at the station.</p><p>Metro's attitude is bad luck for train patrons who expect a reasonable standard of station facility.</p><p>Here is a novel idea: engage a person to sell tickets, look after safety and be responsible for the amenity of the platform. They could have the title ``stationmaster''.</p><p>Phil Bourke, via the web</p><p>We must fix transport</p><p>EVEN the large freeways around Melbourne are becoming heavily congested and not just in peak hour.</p><p>This will continue because of the difficulty of travelling across Melbourne on public transport and the cultural significance of the car. Within 10 years, many suburbs will be so heavily congested that driving will be a nightmare.</p><p>Long-term planning has to begin now.</p><p>Greg Bailey, Nillumbik Northern Greens</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5J9K-3091-JD67-13RW-00000-00<published>2016-03-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Olivia Shying</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PLANTATION firefighters say they have been called to at least 20 forest car fires this fire season alone. </p><p nitf:lede="true">Two cars were torched on Monday morning. The fire quickly spread in a pine plantation however CFA firefighters were able to quickly control the blaze. </p><p>The spate of fires is a cause of concern for authorities. The forest fire comes just days after police investigated a car fire and three other deliberately lit blazes in Creswick. The fires quickly spread into trees and caused damaged to train tracks. CFA operations officer Gavin Hope last week told <emphasis typeStyle="it">The Courier</emphasis> firefighters were continually frustrated by deliberately lit fires, especially during the fire danger period. </p><p>HVP plantation district forester firefighter Bernie Rieniets said the fire burnt 10 square metres and could easily have been much worse if the weather conditions had not been so mild.</p><p>'It was a dewy night ' if it was hot and windy it could have been different,' Mr Rieniets said.</p><p>Mr Rieniets said he had attended more than 20 car fires in the Ballarat area since the fire season started in November. Averaged out, that is nearly five cars a month. </p><p>Data showed 41 cars were found torched in Ballarat between October 2014 and September 2015, more than double the number reported the year prior. </p><p>'(Car fires happen) all the time, the other night we were called to three arches at Creswick,' Mr Rienets said.</p><p>'It is a major concern, this is a pine plantation there is a potential for it to get in (and cause substantial damage).' Mr Rienents said.</p><p>A woman, who wanted to remain anonymous, said she left Ballarat after two cars were stolen from her Alfredton driveway, found torched in the Creswick State Forest two days later. The thieves entered her house while she slept and stole the keys.</p><p>She was forced more than $3000 out of pocket to cover excesses. </p><p>Theresa Jones said her charcoal grey Toyota Hilux dual cab ute was stolen from her Alfredton garage when her husband left the door open for two minutes while he went and picked up his coffee. She was shocked by the brazen theft. The ute, registered ZQS 806, has not been found. On Friday police were called to a car fire in Wendouree ' a Ford worth $7500 was completely destroyed in a suspected arson attack. Call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000. </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
