urn:contentItem:54MM-MX01-JD3N-51PT-00000-00<published>2012-01-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSequence>Pg. 15</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ROYAL MYSTERY</p><p nitf:lede="true">LONDON: British police say they have found human remains on the Queen's Sandringham estate in Norfolk. A brief statement posted on the website of the Norfolk Constabulary said a member of the public had found the remains in an area of woodland at Anmer, a tiny village about 185km northeast of London.</p><p>FATAL INFERNO</p><p>SANTIAGO: A new forest fire has claimed one life in southern Chile just hours after firefighters tamed a massive blaze. The new inferno has consumed</p><p>about 8000ha in southern Chile's Biobio region. A 75-year-old man who refused warnings to leave his home died on Monday.</p><p>WOMEN RESTRICTED</p><p>TRIPOLI: Ten per cent of the seats in a proposed Libyan constituent assembly will be reserved for women, according to a draft electoral law. It has triggered harsh reaction from a human rights watchdog, which said it was outrageous that women would be restricted to only 20 seats.</p><p>LA FIREBUG NABBED</p><p>LOS ANGELES: Authorities have arrested a man in connection with dozens of suspected arsons that have destroyed parked cars, scorched buildings and rattled LA residents over the New Year weekend. Police declined to identify the man, but said he was to be booked on arson charges arising from 53 fires that have flared since Friday in and around Hollywood.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5BD3-MR01-JD6G-40NH-00000-00<published>2014-01-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">IT'S been a hectic week for volunteer firefighters and State Forest personnel after a large number of fires sprang up at once in the wake of Saturday's dry lightning strikes.</p><p>Inspector Mick Holland from Chifley Rural Fire Service said Saturday's conditions were the kind all firefighters dread: lightning, no rain, tinder-dry fuel and scorching temperatures.</p><p>Inspector Holland said 100 RFS crews have been working consistently for the past few weeks and still haven't had a rest since the Lithgow fires.</p><p>Crews were working around the clock to bring these fires under control.</p><p>On Saturday evening there were ten fires burning from Triangle Flat to the south of Oberon and Sunny Corner to the north.</p><p>The fire on a hillside near Lowes Mount Road was quickly contained early on Saturday evening.</p><p>On Monday, cooler weather conditions presented an opportunity to contain the Dog Rocks State Forest fire, but as the wind direction changed, water bombing aircraft were deployed. Black Springs oval was the airbase centre for refuelling.</p><p>Superintendent Tom Shirt from Chifley/Lithgow Rural Fire Service said the heavy water bombing is not to extinguish the fires, but gives the ground crews time to get where they can to do the hard work on the ground.</p><p>On Monday evening, the Dog Rocks Road was closed to all traffic, which left a lot of residents stranded in Black Springs.</p><p>Supt Shirt flew over the Dog Rocks fire ground on Monday and said a lot of expensive pine harvesting machinery had already been lost.</p><p>Crews from all the firefighting agencies ' National Parks, NSW Forestry and the RFS ' were on the fireground.</p><p>'This is the biggest response we have seen for some time and it will carry on for some time,' Supt Shirt said.</p><p>'The beauty of having so many aircraft is that we can respond very quickly.'</p><p>He said all the firefighters on the ground were exhausted.</p><p>Additional strike teams, the majority of which are likely to come from the metropolitan area, will give the local teams a rest.</p><p>'Our volunteers have been doing a truly incredible job out there,' he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">OBERVW-2050496</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">OBERVW2014</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5BD3-MR01-JD6G-40NH-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">390619</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-10-05</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="340"/><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2014 Fairfax Media Publications Pty. urn:contentItem:582M-HYF1-F0NH-V29F-00000-00<published>2013-03-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Keira James</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Concert-goers, performers and organisers at Bundaleer Festival were blessed with the perfect combination of music, food, wine and weather to create an unforgettable weekend this year.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A full program of food for the belly and the soul put smiles on the faces of all in attendance.</p><p>Depending on who you asked, the highlight of the weekend may have been Emma Pask with James Muller and the Bruce Hancock Septet playing late into the night, the welcoming rhythms of African drummers Senoz, the fusion of classical guitar, violin and percussion of Akoustic Odyssey, or soprano Greta Bradman, tenor Rosario La Spina and mezzo-soprano Joanne McWaters with Tim Sexton's Adelaide Art Orchestra performing a variety of pieces from some of the greatest operas.</p><p>The audience had a distinctly pink and lavender hue on Sunday, as little girls and their brothers made crafts and had their faces painted whilst excitedly gathering for The Fairies, Humphrey B Bear and Peter Coombe to appear on stage.</p><p>For older visitors to the forest on Sunday, there were music, stilt walkers, art and poetry readings along the walks through the forest.</p><p>The efforts of CFS volunteers who fought the Bundaleer Forest fire in January were acknowledged by Master of Ceremonies on Saturday, Sonia Feldhoff of 891 ABC Radio Adelaide.</p><p>Praise must go to the organisers of the festival for their hard work in co-ordinating the festival and promoting the event to a cautious public who may have been otherwise deterred from attending after the fire destroyed large tracts of the southern section of the forest.</p><p>Fortunately the northern part of the forest, including the 'hollow' where the main stage was located and Curnow's Camp ground were untouched by the fire.</p><p>CFS units were given complimentary tickets for their volunteers as a thank you and there were many families from brigades all around the Mid North in attendance for the weekend.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5BGW-7SD1-JD6G-40SD-00000-00<published>2014-02-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Members of the Trunkey Rural Bush Fire Brigade thanked the community for its support during the recent bushfire crisis in the district.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Brigade secretary Scott Brown has penned an open letter to the community to acknowledge everyone who helped them during the ordeal.</p><p>'On January 18, due to dry storm activity the Trunkey Creek district experienced several fires which were started by lightning,' Mr Brown's letter states.</p><p>'A major forest fire started west of the village in the Copperhannia Nature Reserve and this fire grew in size and intensity in the days that followed until the village of Trunkey Creek was put on alert for possible evacuation.</p><p>'With the assistance of National Parks and Wildlife Service, NSW Rural Fire Service had large numbers of crews on the ground, as well as up to eight aircraft in the air trying to contain the fire.</p><p>'This level of activity continued for the next week. Several times the fire breached containment lines and these had to be re-established in what was a very trying time for all local residents.</p><p>'In total an area of 2950 hectares was burnt, with a perimeter of 50km.</p><p>'Two weeks later there are still crews on the ground doing the hard yards of blacking out hardwood stumps and  logs.</p><p>'As with all small communities, our own local RFS Brigade of Trunkey spent many long days and nights doing our best to protect the village and potentially our own homes and livelihoods.'</p><p>Mr Brown's letter also noted the generous community support from larger surrounding towns such as Bathurst and Blayney which still amazes all involved. </p><p>'One landowner lost grass country to the fire,' the letter continued. </p><p>'York Ridge Enterprises of Cowra donated a load of much-needed fodder. A special thanks to JTM Earthmoving of Barry who bought in heavy earthmoving equipment at a moment's notice to help contain the fire.</p><p>'Fresh fruit, sausages, snack packs and even bakery delights all found their way onto the fire ground, to tired and hungry firefighters. </p><p>'All donated from these local businesses; IGA of Blayney, Akehurst Bakery, Ryan's Bakery, Aldi Bathurst, Pee Wee's Bakery and Harris Farm of Bathurst, Subway Bathurst, Westpoint IGA of Bathurst, JTM Earthmoving, Argent Minerals, Yarralee Orchard, Blackstump Hotel Trunkey Creek and York Ridge Enterprises.</p><p>'Trunkey Creek RFS would like to extend a huge thank you to all these businesses  for their support.'</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">BLACRO-2077763</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">BLACRO2014</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5BGW-7SD1-JD6G-40SD-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">386746</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2018-03-16</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="396"/><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2014 Fairfax Media Publications Pty. urn:contentItem:4RY6-87H0-TX5J-V10S-00000-00<published>2008-02-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:50Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>quicknewsSmoky tribute</p><p>A PUBLIC memorial concert for country music legend and long-time Ingleside resident Smoky Dawson will be held next month. The Adventures of Smoky Dawson, A Life Remembered will be held on what would have been Dawson's 95th birthday on Wednesday, March 19 at the Hills Performing Arts Centre in Castle Hill. Proceeds will go to one of Dawson's favourite charities for children, Bear Cottage at Manly.</p><p>Firies honoured</p><p>MEMBERS of the Warringah-Pittwater Rural Fire Service were presented with national medals and long-service certificates at a ceremony at the Dee Why Civic Centre on Wednesday. District manager Supt Craig Geddes said the 26 recipients had clocked up a total of 647 years of voluntary service with the RFS, including two who have racked up 50 years apiece. Among those honoured was Keith Joiner, who was the founding captain of the Duffys Forest Fire Brigade, which opened in 1965.</p><p>Go for a paddle</p><p>TAKE a guided environmental tour of the northern beaches as part of Warringah Council's Hilltop to Headland program. An eco-paddle of Narrabeen Lagoon with Tony Carr will explore Middle, Deep, and Mullet Creeks on Saturday, March 8 from 1pm to 5pm. Bookings essential. Details 0417 502 056.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">MANLY-MAN-20080229-1-005-667275</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">MANLYDAILY2008</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4RY6-87H0-TX5J-V10S-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">463826</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2024-01-12</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="203"/><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2008 Nationwide News Pty Limited All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationName>Manly Daily (Australia)</publicationName><edition>1 - urn:contentItem:5HNN-4D41-F0N8-R3YC-00000-00<published>2015-10-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Peter Hannam</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Communities and firefighters could soon receive real-time warnings of risks from bushfires down to a matter of kilometres, according to a new model being tested this fire season.</p><p nitf:lede="true">As fire crews across south-east Australia prepare for an unusually active bushfire season amid an abnormally warm spring and an intensifying El Nino, researchers hope technological advances will soon give communities real-time information on the probability of fire threats down to a resolution of a few kilometres.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"People want to know: It's a fire danger, but a fire danger to what?" says Ross Bradstock, director of the Centre for Environmental Risk Management of Bushfires at the University of Wollongong, and one of the developers of the new model. </p><p>"It incorporates the probability of a fire starting and spreading, based on the fuel and the terrain, and it reaching property," Professor Bradstock said. "The warning system can be tailored to parts of towns or even suburbs."</p><p>The current warning system, modified after the 2009 Black Saturday bushfires in Victoria to include a "catastrophic" threat level, has been based on the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index first developed in the 1960s. That method, however, is based only on weather, such as temperature, relative humidity and wind speed.</p><p>The variables included in the National Fire Danger Rating System Probabilistic Framework range from fuel load and its type, the nature of the terrain and the housing density in a particular region.</p><p>A prototype was tested in the Sydney region including the Blue Mountains and an area east of Melbourne stretching from the Dandenong Ranges to Phillip Island. The model will be tested by fire authorities in NSW this fire season, with the findings to date published by the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre.</p><p>"You can have a region with a lower fire rating but have a particular location with a higher risk," Trent Penman, a bushfire behaviour specialist at the University of Melbourne, and another developer of the new model. "For people in those properties to know they are at higher risk would be beneficial for their preparations."</p><p>Victoria and NSW are divided into large fire districts, and the new model potentially could provide "fine grained" warnings of potential property loss down to five kilometres or less.</p><p>'National priority'</p><p>Richard Thornton, chief executive of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards CRC, said the existing fire danger rating system had been largely unchanged since the 1960s.</p><p>"A new fire danger rating system is a national priority and it is crucial that it is underpinned by the best science available," Dr Thornton said.</p><p>"This is about improving public safety and using science to more accurately predict and communicate bushfire risk," he said. The work is being coordinated by the federal Attorney-General's Department and involves state and territory emergency services, the Bureau of Meteorology, CSIRO, and several universities.</p><p>Kevin Tolhurst, an associate professor in fire ecology at the University of Melbourne, said the probabilistic model was one of several being considered by fire authorities.</p><p>The new system could take "two or three years before it is routine", and a key issue will be how the information is communicated to the public, particularly if warnings become much more detailed.</p><p>While avoiding confusion will be a challenge, the more specific warning may also result in greater involvement from residents.</p><p>"With fire management, you want individuals to respond to what is a community problem," Professor Tolhurst said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4VH3-X9S0-TXX1-F0BY-00000-00<published>2009-02-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>TV GUIDE</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 20</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">In The Line Of Duty: Smoke Jumpers</p><p nitf:lede="true">ACTION/DRAMA **</p><p nitf:lede="true">Noon, Ch 7 (PG)</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Stars: Adam Baldwin (pictured) Lindsay Frost, Timothy Carhart.</p><p>The Story: Based on a true account, this follows the heroic story of a group of firefighters who courageously parachuted into a raging forest fire in order to stop the fiery destruction.</p><p>The Verdict: Brave or just barking mad? The action scenes are gripping but the romantic back burn fails to ignite.</p><p>Everybody Is A Killer</p><p>BLACK COMEDY **</p><p>10pm, SBS (M)</p><p>The Stars: Samuel Le Bihan, Franois Berleand, Nadia Fares.</p><p>The Story: Tale of lies, collective hysteria and small-town life, in which the local mechanic becomes a hero after he's accused of murdering the town bully.</p><p>The Verdict: Intriguing enough little Belgian flick that's a curious but hardly compelling mix of black comedy and old-fashioned whodunit.</p><p>Casbah</p><p>CRIME ***</p><p>2am, ABC1 (PG)</p><p>The Stars: Peter Lorre, Yvonne De Carlo, Tony Martin.</p><p>The Story: Follows the original tale about the thief who hides in the Casbah but is finally lured to his death by a beautiful girl (De Carlo).</p><p>The Verdict: Familiar period screen fodder lifted by a peppy story, some bouncy music (Leo Robin-Harold Arlen tunes) and good performances. Martin is great as a dashing pimpernel of a thief whose elusive ways drive the cops to despair.</p><p>THE STAR SYSTEM</p><p>***** Classic, worth staying in for</p><p>**** Excellent, time well spent</p><p>*** Good, enjoyable two hours on the couch</p><p>** OK if there's nothing else on</p><p>* Spend your money on a good DVD</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>NSW: Coast fires contained but inland scrub alight_2</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p><br/>Bushfires NSW  D/L 2 Sydney<br/><br/>Mr Winter said containing a forest fire near the Olympic<br/>shooting venue at Cecil Hills yesterday had been difficult, despite<br/>100 firefighters and 25 vehicles at the scene.<br/>            High tension power-lines hampered helicopter water-bombing<br/>efforts, and soft soil blocked vehicle access.</p><p>           "The ground was too soft for us to drive our trucks onto, so we<br/>had to wait for (the fire) to burn to the road," he said.<br/>            Mr Winter said the fire was contained within two hours.<br/>            The Bureau of Meteorology said milder weather throughout the day<br/>and a possible afternoon storm would aid firefighting.<br/>            "Conditions have improved, but not enough to extinguish the<br/>fires naturally," said senior meteorologist Brett Gage.<br/>            Mr Gage said the fires had exacerbated this morning's fog in<br/>Sydney, with smoke particles forming nucleii for the mist.<br/>            The NSW Environment Protection Authority said Sydney air<br/>pollution had returned to low levels and the open fire burning ban,<br/>due to finish at midnight, would not be extended.<br/>            Firefighter numbers are expected to be reduced later today.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source A002</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>The Canberra Times</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Guilty plea to rape A Canberra taxi driver has pleaded guilty to raping a passenger as he drove her home after a night out in Civic. Neelander Neel Sirohi, 31, picked the woman up at 3.20am from a taxi rank near the Civic bus interchange on Alinga Street in August 2013. The woman was extremely vulnerable when she got in the car. She was heavily intoxicated, having consumed alcohol and prescription medication, and remembered feeling sleepy during the drive. Sirohi sexually assaulted her while she was in the front seat. He then took her back to his home in Harrison, and again sexually assaulted her before dropping her home. The victim told police she had little memory of the ordeal. She made a complaint soon after, police alleged in earlier court documents, telling her mother: "Something happened to me, it was the taxi driver." The woman was later medically examined. Sirohi initially denied her claims to police and pleaded not guilty to the allegations in the ACT Magistrates Court. But he appeared in the ACT Supreme Court on Wednesday and was arraigned on two counts of sexual intercourse without consent.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Sirohi, represented by barrister James Sabharwal, pleaded guilty to both counts. Justice John Burns ordered a pre-sentence report be completed, and Sirohi will be brought back to court in August.</p><p>Braddon robbery A man armed with a knife has robbed a small Braddon supermarket on Tuesday in what is the fifth Canberra robbery in three weeks. The man threatened an employee with a knife inside the Lowana Street store about 6pm, demanding cash. The worker handed over the cash and the offender fled towards Northbourne Avenue. The man is described as of Caucasian appearance and tall with a slim build. He was wearing a maroon or purple hooded jumper, with a face covering and sunglasses.</p><p>ACT Policing and the AFP Forensic Service attended the scene and found an empty bag the offender dropped during the robbery. Police will forensically examine the bag.</p><p>ACT Policing is also seeking CCTV footage. The Braddon incident is the fifth aggravated robbery in the capital in three weeks and the fourth involving at least one knife. Just a day earlier a man carrying a large knife robbed a city convenience store and threatened a staff member. Police have urged anyone who may have witnessed the incident or has any information that could assist police to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or via act.crimestoppers.com.au Information can be provided anonymously.</p><p>Forest fire smoke A series of hazard reduction burns at Kowen Forest in the next week are expected to shift smoke across Canberra. An ACT Parks and Conservation Service spokesman said the burns would begin on Wednesday and should be be completed next week, weather permitting. The fires would will burn through several piles of forest debris spread across 30 hectares. The spokesman said firefighters tried to undertake burns in weather conditions that minimised the impact of smoke on Canberra residents, however some smoke was expected across the ACT.</p><p>Experienced Parks and Conservation fire managers and firefighters will conduct the burning operations and staff will monitor the burn site until smoke has not been visible for 24 hours. ACT Health has advised people with asthma and other chronic respiratory or chronic cardiac diseases to avoid vigorous exercise and to stay inside where possible if affected by the smoke.</p><p>For more information, visit <url normalizedValue="http://www.tams.act.gov.au">www.tams.act.gov.au</url> or phone Canberra Connect on 13 22 81.</p><p>Police dog's close call A police dog has escaped injury in a two-car crash in Fyshwick on Wednesday. The dog was travelling in the back of a police vehicle on Newcastle Street when a second car rear-ended the cop car, an ACT Policing spokeswoman said. The police officer and his dog were on duty at the time of the 12.45pm crash. The spokeswoman said the crash was minor and the dog and driver were not harmed.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
